answers.answer: It is very difficult to detect heart problems in patients without symptoms, as happens often in patients with diabetes mellitus. These patients often present very late and their heart problems are often misdiagnosed because the symptoms are absent or very atypical. What can one do? Well, one can have a high index of suspicion for these issues in patients with high risk for heart disease such as those with prior history of heart problems or heart attack survivors. There are presently no blood tests to predict impending heart attacks, but only labs that detect heart damage once it has occurred.

question: My uncle passed away Monday from a massive heart attack.  We learned Monday night that he had not been feeling "good" for the last two weeks.  In the research that I have done since Monday, I cannot find anything saying the symptoms/signs could begin weeks before.  Most websites state everything in hours.  What are the signs that one should look for that could be early detectors?  He didn't complain of shortness of breath, pain or anything in the few hours he lived Monday.  He was at work and just died.  Please tell me if there any other warning signs besides the obvious ones that are posted on various websites.  What are tests that one should do and how often should they be performed?  Thank you in advance for your assistance.
title: Massive Heart Attack
